---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

nodes.body:
Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6929481024/job/18847272228)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6929481024/job/18847273259)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/6929481024/job/18847272775)
`Disjoint` really isn't bad to work with IMO, so we should standardise on that.

What do you think of
```suggestion
    (S : Submonoid Î±) (disjoint : Disjoint (I : Set Î±) S)
```
and similarly for `maximally_disjoint`?

I think `Disjoint` isn't very nice definitionally (requires [disjoint_iff](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Order/Disjoint.html#disjoint_iff) to convert to the current form), and `Â¬ Disjoint` would be a bit awkward (`((I : Set Î±) âˆ© S).Nonempty` is probably definitionally most convenient), so I'm happy with the current statement. Note that `âˆ©` should be used instead of `âŠ“` since these are sets.

The point of `Disjoint` is precisely to normalise alll those context-specific uses to a single canonical spelling, though.
You will remark that `(I : Set Î±) âŠ“ S = âˆ…` is actually very bad definitionally. You can't apply it nor have dot notation on it!

I am strongly in favour of Eric's suggestion.

I agree, we should consistently use `Disjoint` here. See also this analogous Zulip discussion on `IsCoprime`: https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/coprime.20ideal/near/395055642.

@YaelDillies, do we have some predicate that combines these two, as the more general
```lean
    (p : P I)
    (maximally_p : âˆ€ (J : Ideal Î±), P J â†’ I < J â†’ False) :
```
There's `IsMaxOn`, but weirdly it uses `Filter` ðŸ¤”

I tried using `IsMaxOn` here but the API is very much lacking. For example, you cannot easily get Eric's `maximally_p` out of it. So I think the current spelling of `maximally_disjoint` is okay, if we switch to `Disjoint`:
```suggestion
    (S : Submonoid Î±) (disjoint : Disjoint (I : Set Î±) S)
    (maximally_disjoint : âˆ€ (J : Ideal Î±), I < J â†’ Â¬ Disjoint (J : Set Î±) S) :
```

a bit of golf
```
lemma isPrime_of_maximally_disjoint (I : Ideal Î±)
    (S : Submonoid Î±) (disjoint : (I : Set Î±) âˆ© S = âˆ…)
    (maximally_disjoint : âˆ€ (J : Ideal Î±), I < J â†’ (J : Set Î±) âˆ© S â‰  âˆ…) :
    I.IsPrime where
  ne_top' := by rintro rfl; exact disjoint.subset âŸ¨trivial, S.one_memâŸ©
  mem_or_mem' {x y} hxy := by
    by_contra' rid
    have hx := maximally_disjoint (I âŠ” span {x}) (Submodule.lt_sup_iff_not_mem.mpr rid.1)
    have hy := maximally_disjoint (I âŠ” span {y}) (Submodule.lt_sup_iff_not_mem.mpr rid.2)
    simp_rw [â† nonempty_iff_ne_empty, nonempty_def, mem_inter_iff,
      SetLike.mem_coe, Submodule.mem_sup, mem_span_singleton] at hx hy
    obtain âŸ¨sâ‚, âŸ¨iâ‚, hiâ‚, âŸ¨_, âŸ¨râ‚, rflâŸ©, hrâ‚âŸ©âŸ©, hsâ‚âŸ© := hx
    obtain âŸ¨sâ‚‚, âŸ¨iâ‚‚, hiâ‚‚, âŸ¨_, âŸ¨râ‚‚, rflâŸ©, hrâ‚‚âŸ©âŸ©, hsâ‚‚âŸ© := hy
    refine eq_empty_iff_forall_not_mem.mp disjoint (sâ‚ * sâ‚‚) âŸ¨hrâ‚ â–¸ hrâ‚‚ â–¸ ?_, S.mul_mem hsâ‚ hsâ‚‚âŸ©
    ring_nf
    rw [show x * râ‚ * y * râ‚‚ = (x * y) * (râ‚ * râ‚‚) by ring]
    exact I.add_mem (I.add_mem (I.add_mem (I.mul_mem_left _ hiâ‚‚) <| I.mul_mem_right _ <|
      I.mul_mem_right _ hiâ‚) <| I.mul_mem_left _ hiâ‚‚) (I.mul_mem_right _ hxy)
```

Here's an alternative proof if you use `Disjoint` above:
```suggestion
    have : 1 âˆˆ (S : Set Î±) := S.one_mem
    aesop
```

Further golfing using `Disjoint`:
```suggestion
    by_contra' rid
    have hx := maximally_disjoint (I âŠ” span {x}) (Submodule.lt_sup_iff_not_mem.mpr rid.1)
    have hy := maximally_disjoint (I âŠ” span {y}) (Submodule.lt_sup_iff_not_mem.mpr rid.2)
    simp only [Set.not_disjoint_iff, mem_inter_iff, SetLike.mem_coe, Submodule.mem_sup,
      mem_span_singleton] at hx hy
    obtain âŸ¨sâ‚, âŸ¨iâ‚, hiâ‚, âŸ¨_, âŸ¨râ‚, rflâŸ©, hrâ‚âŸ©âŸ©, hsâ‚âŸ© := hx
    obtain âŸ¨sâ‚‚, âŸ¨iâ‚‚, hiâ‚‚, âŸ¨_, âŸ¨râ‚‚, rflâŸ©, hrâ‚‚âŸ©âŸ©, hsâ‚‚âŸ© := hy
    refine disjoint.ne_of_mem
      (I.add_mem (I.mul_mem_left (iâ‚ + x * râ‚) hiâ‚‚) <| I.add_mem (I.mul_mem_right (y * râ‚‚) hiâ‚) <|
        I.mul_mem_right (râ‚ * râ‚‚) hxy)
      (S.mul_mem hsâ‚ hsâ‚‚) ?_
    rw [â† hrâ‚, â† hrâ‚‚]
    ring
```
Thanks and sorry for forgetting about the PR. I can now agree that using `Disjoint` API is good practice, having worked with it a bit in other contexts.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/Ideal/Basic): an ideal is prime if it is maximally disjoint from a submonoid
